title_full: CMOBSEC01-BP01 Personally identifiable information (PII) and unique identifiers assigned to a vehicle or consumer should be anonymized
title: Personally identifiable information (PII) and unique identifiers assigned to a vehicle or consumer should be anonymized
description: Information which can be used to directly or indirectly identify an individual must be protected from disclosure including name, address, location data, VIN, and IMEI. This data should be encrypted in transit using secure protocols such as TLS and at rest using robust encryption keys. Restrict access to data for authorized users by classifying data and creating separate views.
outcome: Protected consumer privacy with encrypted and anonymized PII and vehicle identifiers

title_full: CMOBSEC01-BP02 Location data collected from navigation systems should be appropriately secured to protect anonymity
title: Location data collected from navigation systems should be appropriately secured to protect anonymity
description: Data which can be used to locate a consumer or track travel routes should be encrypted in transit and at rest. Location data sent to third parties should have any PII or IDs scrubbed from the request. The precision of coordinates for latitude and longitude can be adjusted to provide additional privacy.
outcome: Secure location data with appropriate privacy controls and coordinate precision management

title_full: CMOBSEC01-BP03 Data collected from cameras, microphones, biometric, and other types of sensors should be appropriately secured
title: Data collected from cameras, microphones, biometric, and other types of sensors should be appropriately secured
description: Sensors should only collect the minimum amount of data required to facilitate their function. Use wake words or tactile buttons to begin data collection, implement idle timeout logic, blur identifying features in images, and use strong encryption in transit and at rest.
outcome: Minimized and secured sensor data collection with privacy-preserving techniques

title_full: CMOBSEC03-BP01 Securely manage the lifecycle of identities and credentials for your vehicles and ECUs
title: Securely manage the lifecycle of identities and credentials for your vehicles and ECUs
description: Implement secure processes for provisioning, enrolling, validating, renewing, revoking, and retiring X.509 certificates and other credentials for vehicles and ECUs. Use secure hardware modules for private key generation, implement certificate rotation, and use CRLs or OCSP for revocation checking.
outcome: Comprehensive identity lifecycle management for vehicles and ECUs with secure certificate management

title_full: CMOBSEC03-BP02 Design and securely operate a PKI for vehicle identities
title: Design and securely operate a PKI for vehicle identities
description: Document PKI policies and practices including CA structure, validity periods, succession planning, administrative controls, and roles. Minimize use of root CA, store root CA private keys in HSMs with tight access controls, and review supplier CP/CPS when sharing PKI components.
outcome: Secure vehicle PKI with documented policies and practices, protected root CA, and supplier oversight

title_full: CMOBSEC03-BP03 Design a mechanism to tie various vehicle identities together as necessary
title: Design a mechanism to tie various vehicle identities together as necessary
description: Based on application needs, implement the ability to map and correlate multiple identities per ECU and per vehicle to enable appropriate access control and authorization decisions.
outcome: Correlated vehicle and ECU identities enabling proper access control decisions

title_full: CMOBSEC09-BP01 Collect and detect events using onboard components in the vehicle
title: Collect and detect events using onboard components in the vehicle
description: Implement software that can detect vehicle attacks and raise events to an IDS manager on the ECU. Events are passed to local event memory for storage and analyzed by authorized users, with the majority sent to the VSOC system for further refinement.
outcome: In-vehicle intrusion detection with local event storage and VSOC integration

title_full: CMOBSEC09-BP02 Ingest and enrich data by preparing, moving, aggregating, normalizing, transforming, and analyzing vehicle data
title: Ingest and enrich data by preparing, moving, aggregating, normalizing, transforming, and analyzing vehicle data
description: Build a pipeline to ingest vehicle data using AWS IoT Fleetwise or other protocols, store in S3 or Security Lake, process with AWS Glue, analyze with SageMaker AI, and visualize with QuickSight, Managed Grafana, or OpenSearch with Kibana.
outcome: Comprehensive vehicle security data pipeline from ingestion through visualization

title_full: CMOBSEC10-BP01 Gather relevant supplier, vendor, production, API, and partner data to enhance detection mechanisms
title: Gather relevant supplier, vendor, production, API, and partner data to enhance detection mechanisms
description: Collect logs from backend systems, companion APIs, charging stations, diagnostics databases, AUTOSAR XML databases, production data, and partners. Correlate this data to build detection rules based on trained models and integrate threat intelligence feeds.
outcome: Enhanced security detection through correlation of diverse data sources and threat intelligence

title_full: CMOBSEC11-BP01 Detect security posture deviations and anomalous behavior
title: Detect security posture deviations and anomalous behavior
description: Monitor ECUs continuously for security best practices, certificate and CA expiration, revocation status, and overly permissive actions. Track changes in vehicle patterns that significantly deviate from known expected baselines.
outcome: Continuous monitoring of ECU security posture with anomaly detection

title_full: CMOBSEC13-BP01 Define a baseline of normal behavior for your vehicle and reject and alert on deviations
title: Define a baseline of normal behavior for your vehicle and reject and alert on deviations
description: Implement a solution to create a baseline of metrics for vehicles within your fleet. Use AWS IoT Device Defender Security Profiles to detect anomalies such as impossible motion speeds or vehicles existing in multiple locations simultaneously, triggering alerts and automated mitigation actions.
outcome: Behavioral baseline monitoring with automated anomaly detection and response

title_full: CMOBSEC14-BP01 Conduct threat modeling using formal methodology on in-vehicle systems
title: Conduct threat modeling using formal methodology on in-vehicle systems
description: Conduct threat modeling using formal methodologies such as MITRE Threat Assessment and Threat Analysis Risk Assessment (TARA) on in-vehicle systems.
outcome: Comprehensive threat models for in-vehicle systems using industry-standard methodologies

title_full: CMOBSEC14-BP02 Conduct tests on ECUs to determine unnecessary configurations and vulnerabilities
title: Conduct tests on ECUs to determine unnecessary configurations and vulnerabilities
description: Conduct tests on ECUs to determine if there are any unnecessary configurations such as open ports, default permissions, unnecessary services running, or other vulnerabilities.
outcome: Identified and remediated ECU vulnerabilities and unnecessary configurations

title_full: CMOBSEC14-BP03 Develop requirements and processes to address and remediate vulnerabilities
title: Develop requirements and processes to address and remediate vulnerabilities
description: Develop requirements and processes to address and remediate vulnerabilities discovered through testing.
outcome: Documented vulnerability remediation requirements and processes

title_full: CMOBSEC15-BP01 Validate all software updates are cryptographically signed upon release and verified before installation
title: Validate all software updates are cryptographically signed upon release and verified before installation
description: For devices using AWS IoT, software updates can be signed using AWS Signer. All actions within AWS Signer are captured in AWS CloudTrail for auditing purposes.
outcome: Cryptographically signed and verified software updates with audit trail

title_full: CMOBSEC15-BP02 Test software packages for vulnerabilities and errors prior to deployment
title: Test software packages for vulnerabilities and errors prior to deployment
description: Test software packages for vulnerabilities and errors prior to deployment.
outcome: Validated software packages free of known vulnerabilities before deployment

title_full: CMOBSEC15-BP03 Perform controlled and secure deployment of software to vehicle fleets with rollback capabilities
title: Perform controlled and secure deployment of software to vehicle fleets with rollback capabilities
description: Perform controlled and secure deployment of software to vehicle fleets with rollback capabilities in case of failures.
outcome: Safe software deployment with rollback capabilities to minimize fleet-wide issues

title_full: CMOBSEC16-BP01 Maintain an accurate and continuously updated inventory of vehicles and components
title: Maintain an accurate and continuously updated inventory of vehicles and components
description: Maintain an accurate and continuously updated inventory of vehicles and any versions of software packages or underlying hardware. Include Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) documents and Vulnerability Exploitability eXchange (VEX) documents.
outcome: Comprehensive vehicle and component inventory with SBOM and VEX documentation

title_full: CMOBSEC17-BP01 Use methods for ensuring integrity such as secure boot and software signing
title: Use methods for ensuring integrity such as secure boot and software signing
description: Use methods for ensuring integrity such as through secure boot and software signing methodologies.
outcome: Verified software integrity through secure boot and code signing

title_full: CMOBSEC18-BP01 Develop SDLC policies which govern security requirements
title: Develop SDLC policies which govern security requirements
description: Develop SDLC policies which govern these requirements and provide prescriptive guidance for implementing required controls.
outcome: Documented SDLC security policies and implementation guidance

title_full: CMOBSEC19-BP01 Continuously monitor threat intelligence feeds from vendors, suppliers, and communities
title: Continuously monitor threat intelligence feeds from vendors, suppliers, and communities
description: Continuously monitor informational feeds on threat intelligence from vendors, suppliers, third-party intelligence providers, repositories, and communities. Use AWS Partners like Recorded Future, Tenable, and Auto-ISAC for automotive-specific threat intelligence.
outcome: Integrated threat intelligence from multiple sources informing security posture

title_full: CMOBSEC19-BP02 Conduct vulnerability impact analysis and testing in isolated environments
title: Conduct vulnerability impact analysis and testing in isolated environments
description: When conducting tests of vulnerabilities or investigating potentially compromised systems, use isolated and secure environments such as separate AWS Accounts with strong defense-in-depth configurations.
outcome: Safe vulnerability testing without risk to production systems

title_full: CMOBSEC19-BP03 Define a process for classifying and prioritizing vulnerabilities for remediation
title: Define a process for classifying and prioritizing vulnerabilities for remediation
description: Processes for classification, prioritization, and remediation of vulnerabilities should be formally documented and readily accessible to stakeholders. Use playbooks and runbooks specific to your technology stack with automation through Jupyter Notebooks or AWS Systems Manager.
outcome: Documented vulnerability management process with automated remediation capabilities

title_full: CMOBSEC20-BP01 Implement TLS 1.2+ to encrypt data in transit
title: Implement TLS 1.2+ to encrypt data in transit
description: Implement TLS 1.2+ from the ECU to the connected vehicle service backend for encryption in transit. With X.509 client certificates for mutual TLS, you also get authorization of requests.
outcome: Encrypted and authenticated communications using TLS 1.2+ with mutual authentication

title_full: CMOBSEC20-BP02 Consider client-side encryption of highly sensitive data at the ECU
title: Consider client-side encryption of highly sensitive data at the ECU
description: For highly sensitive data, implement client-side encryption at the ECU before transmission. Use envelope encryption with AWS KMS and the AWS Encryption SDK with data key caching to improve performance while keeping sensitive data encrypted end-to-end.
outcome: End-to-end encryption of highly sensitive data from ECU to backend

title_full: CMOBSEC21-BP01 Do not use sensitive data to name and reference resources
title: Do not use sensitive data to name and reference resources
description: Avoid using sensitive data such as VIN, customer identity, or location in resource names. Use hashed VINs or other unique identifiers that cannot be mapped to a VIN to limit exposure in logs and subscriptions.
outcome: Reduced exposure of sensitive data through use of non-sensitive resource identifiers

title_full: CMOBSEC22-BP01 Define VSOC capabilities and requirements, then develop and test your incident response plan
title: Define VSOC capabilities and requirements, then develop and test your incident response plan
description: Define VSOC capabilities aligned with compliance requirements, prepare incident response plans and runbooks, implement SOAR and ticketing capabilities, and run game days and tabletop exercises to practice incident response.
outcome: Comprehensive VSOC with tested incident response capabilities

title_full: CMOBSEC22-BP02 Train or outsource personnel to manage security incidents at multiple complexity tiers
title: Train or outsource personnel to manage security incidents at multiple complexity tiers
description: Determine if your organization has the resources, processes, and skills to address vehicle incidents at multiple tiers based on severity and complexity. Consider partnering with AWS Partners or vendors for managed VSOC services.
outcome: Skilled or outsourced incident response capabilities across all severity levels

title_full: CMOBSEC23-BP01 Mitigate and respond to potential incidents by creating and testing policies, procedures, and playbooks
title: Mitigate and respond to potential incidents by creating and testing policies, procedures, and playbooks
description: Use runbooks to automate workflow tasks like notifying stakeholders and creating tickets. Build workflows that can inactivate or revoke certificates and block communications to AWS IoT Core while investigating incidents. Follow incident response procedures to recover vehicles to non-compromised states.
outcome: Automated incident response workflows with vehicle containment and recovery capabilities

title_full: CMOBSEC24-BP01 Digitally sign software and firmware with certificates verifiable during runtime
title: Digitally sign software and firmware with certificates verifiable during runtime
description: Consider digitally signing software and firmware with certificates that can be verified by vehicle hardware during runtime ensuring only trusted code runs. Use AWS Private CA for code signing certificates and AWS Signer for IoT device code signing.
outcome: Verified trusted code execution through digital signatures and secure boot

title_full: CMOBSEC25-BP01 Implement a Secure Development Lifecycle (SDLC) for vehicle software following open standards
title: Implement a Secure Development Lifecycle (SDLC) for vehicle software following open standards
description: Create cybersecurity metrics and requirements per ISO 21434. Create threat models using STRIDE or TARA framework. Implement secure coding following AUTOSAR and ASPICE guidelines with input validation, buffer overflow protection, and error handling. Conduct code reviews, security audits, and testing in simulated and real-world scenarios.
outcome: Secure vehicle software development following industry standards and best practices
